As important as Bardeen, Brattain, and Shockley’s invention of the transistor was, its effectiveness was greatly magnified by the invention of the integrated circuit. Jack Kilby of Texas Instruments created a basic prototype in 1958 and eventually was awarded the patent and a Nobel Prize in Physics for his work. Many others made significant contributions.Regardless of who gets the lion’s share of the credit, one thing everyone agrees on is the incredible impact IC’s have had on our civilization. It isn’t just the capabilities of these amazing devices that have made them important. It’s the stunning exponential increase in those capabilities. Ever since they went into mass manufacturing in the 1960’s, IC’s have doubled in computational power about every 2 years. This growth over the course of half a century is unprecedented in the history of humankind. No other invention has ever doubled it’s power every 2 years for 50 years.IC’s were crucial to the creation of the Internet, itself a game-changing invention. A 10 year old sitting in his bedroom can post content that can be seen across the world within seconds. Even the most powerful people in the world didn’t have that ability 50 years ago.This exponential growth trend is referred to as Moore’s Law after the Intel engineer who was one of the first industry leaders to recognize and popularize it. As Moore himself often pointed out, Moore’s Law isn’t really a law. It’s just a trend that naturally emerged because of the balance between technical capabilities and economic realities. The laws of physics and economics will inevitably put a stop to Moore’s Law. Indeed, the last few years have shown a noticeable deviation from Moore’s Law as transistor dimensions approach the 1 nanometer scale.How will our civilization adjust to the end of Moore’s Law? Will it be a soft landing or a crash landing that takes down governments and industries? Will other technologies such as DNA manipulation or quantum computing step up to take its place?
